docs.abstract: Article on rising number of teenage boys on Long Island who, preparing for summer on the beach, are obsessed with body-building and weight-lifting to improve their body images; some, though it is not certain how many, are taking anabolic steroids, which are illegal, and dietary supplements, which are not but may pose health risks; teenage girls are also flocking to gyms, tweaking their diets and some have taken up weight-training; school coaches and gym owners and trainers comment; photos (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: ON a recent sunny Saturday at the Central Mall, Jones Beach's answer to Muscle Beach, Josh Joseph, a young man with a massive build, a deep tan and a pierced tongue, stood surveying this year's crop of hardbodies. Mr. Joseph, from Bellmore, is 19 and delivers pizza to support his work in progress: making his big body bigger at the Powerhouse Gym in Bellmore. Over the past two months, he added 40 pounds of muscle to his already strapping 230-pound frame by regularly shooting anabolic steroids into his buttocks.

headline.main: Web Sites Inconsistent On Health, Study Finds

docs.abstract: RAND Corp study for California Health Care Foundation finds health data on Internet is often hard to find, hard to read, incorrect or incomplete, even on best sites; Dr Gretchen K Berland, study lead author, says most people will be frustrated searching Web for health data, phone interview (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A new study has found that most of the time, health information on the Internet is hard to find, hard to read and often incorrect or incomplete, even on the best sites. The study, described in today's Journal of the American Medical Association, is the broadest on the topic to date; it includes detailed questions on four diseases, rates the difficulty of finding information and the site's reading level, and assesses its accuracy and completeness. The study includes Spanish-language sites.
docs.snippet: A new study has found that most of the time, health information on the Internet is hard to find, hard to read and often incorrect or incomplete, even on the best sites.    The study, described in today's Journal of the American Medical Association,...

headline.main: Extra Pounds Not as Risky in Elderly

docs.abstract: Researchers at Yale may have found another upside to aging: they say national guidelines about weight gain should probably be relaxed for the elderly, and there is little evidence that older people who are moderately overweight are at greater risk of illness or death (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers at Yale may have found another upside to aging: they say national guidelines about weight gain should probably be relaxed for the elderly. In a study published this month in The Archives of Internal Medicine, Dr. Asefeh Heiat and Dr. Harlan M. Krumholz argued that there was little evidence that older people who were moderately overweight were at greater risk of illness or death. They cautioned that obesity and near obesity were still associated with an increased risk of death, even among people over 75.
